TAU BETA PI
INITIATES THREE
E. W. Vivell, Anatoli Seletzky, and Edward S. Loane
were initiated into membership of Tau Beta Pi, honorary
engineering fraternity, at the
public initiation yesterday in
assembly. Both Vivell and
Seletzky are seniors, while
Loane is a member of the junior class.
Mr. Thomas F. Hubbard,
himself a graduate of Hopkins and a member of both
Tau Beta Pi and Omicron
Delta Kappa, was the principal speaker at the initiation.
The private initiation was
held last night at the Southern
Hotel, and was followed by
the customary banquet in honor of the new members.

Entered as second-class matter December 3, 1909, at the Postoffice at
Baltimore, Md., under Act of Congress, November 3, 1879.
Published semi-weekly from October to June by the students of Johns
Hopkins University.

Business communications should be addressed to the BUSINESS MANA—
GER, JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY; all articles and other communications
:should be sent to the MANAGING EDITOR.

Printed by The Read-Taylor Press, South and Lombard Streets

CONGRATULATIONS
The NEws-LETTER wishes to extend its congratulations to
the newly elected members of Tau Beta Pi. While the engineering society is not as widely known as is Phi Beta Kappa, election
to membership is as highly esteemed in engineering circles as
election to Phi Beta Kappa in scholarly circles.
Because of the high standards of the Johns Hopkins Engineering Department, membership in the local chapter is an even
greater honor than it would seem to the average undergraduate.

CHAMPIONS
"Everything comes to him who waits." Once again the patentold adage has been, Nlfilled. Although the Hopuntrustworthy
ly
kins lacrosse team completed its wonderfully successful season
last May, it was not until a few days ago that they received their
official reward.
Intercollegiate lacrosse champions of the country! There
was never any doubt of their deserving the .title, but it gives us
a great deal of satisfaction in knowing that they actually have it.
We rush to congratulate last year's team and Coaches Van Orman
and Schmeisser for bringing to Hopkins another national lacrosse
championship.

REGULATIONS STILL WITH US
Freshman dreams of escaping regulations for the remainder
of the term were rather rudely dashed by the events of last Saturday. Determination and spirit the first year men displayed
in abundance, but these factors did. not prove to be enough, as a
defeat in football and a tie in the rush indicate.
Wish. to congratulate both teams. For an interclass contest
the game- was well played; and the spectators in spite of nearly
freezing to death, seemed to enjoy it.
- Although we sympathize with the freshmen in their shattered
hopes, we trust that now sophomores have won _the right to en-force regulations they will exercise it. Although 'regulations have
often been criticised as both childish and useless, they undoubtedly are a valuable contribution to an introduction to undergraduate life. That they are somewhat childish no one will deny—
but why expect or desire an undergraduate to be completely
grown up.?

YES and NO

mbassy
E
THEATRE

"Just Around the Corner from City Hall Plaza"

Hurrah! An undergrad who isn't afraid to express a thought
We knew that if we kept at it long enough, we should receive
something like the communication we print below. Le voici.
To the Editor of YES AND No:
While I am in an overworked condition, as are all Hopkins
undergraduates, and, as I shall proceed to demonstrate, utterly
incapable of expression, I may fulfill the somewhat Utopian
dream of an undergraduate who thinks, or thinks he thinks. I
cannot be at all sure whether the ravings of "Yes and No" are
prompted by a desire to find "copy" that will fill space or by a
real interest in what the undergraduate thinks, if at all. However, here goes:
I think that a college edtication, for four out of every five
college men, is a waste of time and money. I should exclude the
Engineers who get from their work something that it would be
difficult if not impossible for them to obtain outside an institution of learning. My statement applies particularly to the several hundred students in the College of Arts and Sciences who,
after four years of more or less hard work, receive an A. B. degree and go forth into the "cold world" and attempt to secure
therefrom a decent living. What does such a man get from his
college career to help him be successful in life? What is success
in life from the undergraduate point of view? To me happiness
is success, happiness in doing whatever I may want to do whether
it be drinking liquor or shaping the destinies of nations. These
questions certainly should interest every undergraduate and he
must think about them if he thinks at all.
We are told that college broadens us. What is broadening,
and after all are we certain that broadening is a desirable thing?
May not broadening lead a man to unhappiness by creating in him
desires that he can never satisfy?
We are told that college teaches us to think. Does it? Does
college make a man more capable of solving the many problems
of life which present themselves to him?
I was much interested in an article by Corey Ford in a recent issue of "College Humor" because it explains so well what I
think to be the ideal way to spend four years in college. Mr.
Ford says: "If I had a son (in college) I'd give him all the
money he could possibly spend. I'd tell him to read a great deal
of the books he Wants to read, go to a lot of theaters, and have
parties now and then; and if he came home with a degree I'd
disown him. I'd warn him to stay away from extra-curricular
activities, and I'd tell him to cut a class whenever he found
someone worth talking to." Perhaps these ideas are all wrong
but it seems to me that if it's broadening we are after this system should certainly give it to us. What do you think?
In order to insure sufficient "copy" for "Yes and No" I add
that I do enjoy looking at beautiful women, I do enjoy gambling
in all its forms, and drinking at least sufficient alcohol to make
my heart glad if there is reason why it should be glad. I hereby
challenge the more righteous among us, including the Y. M. C. A.,
to tell me why I shouldn't do these things if I so desire and I
hope that I can find someone who will help me to answer, in connection with college, the old question, "What's it all about ?"

There you have it. George Noneof-Your-Business Drury or Drurey.

The first dormitory dance of the
year will be held this evening in
the Commons Room. The SimpsonNIorris orchestra will furnish the
music for the evening's entertainment. Tuxedos will be the apparel
for the well-dressed man. The
dance will begin at nine and continue to one. A number of tickets
have already been sold to residents
at the popular subscription price of
one fifty per couple. Stags are welcome but not encouraged. Residents
are privileged to invite friends.
Every resident should be present

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, DECEMBER 10, 1926

th

R. 0. T. C. HEADQUARTERS
ARE MOVED
Continued from Page 1, Col. 1
tower room, he believed, was to be
utilized by the Librarian.
This statement was verified by
Dr. L. M. Raney, Librarian. The
tower room will perform the function of a repository for duplicate
books and a receiving office. What
are now the postoffice and the telephone room on the ground floor and
the ladies' rest room on the third
floor of Gilman Hall had been primarily intended for these purposes,
said Dr. Raney. Since other necessities prevented such use, the Library stocks have been used instead.
Graduate students have been hampered and valuable spaces in the tiers
and on the tables has been taken
up by idle stock, which will now be
removed to the tower room. Voluminous sets which arrive will be received here also, instead of in the
stacks, so that indexing and cataloging may be done with more care
and with hindrance to no one.

BLOND gentlemen and dark-haired gentlemen,
diffident* freshmen and august seniors . . .
Prince Albert is the overwhelming campusfavorite of every type and every pipe. (Yes,
the pipes do have a voice in the matter. They
can act in a docile, friendly manner or they can
be mean. It depends on what you feed them.)
Open a tidy red tin of good old P. A. That
first fragrant whiff will tell you why gentlemen
prefer Prince Albert. Tuck a load into the bowl
of your pipe and light up. Fragrance and taste
alone are enough to win you.
But P. A. doesn't stop there. It is coolsmoking. It is mild as Maytime, yet it has
plenty of body. It is kind to your tongue and
throat. You can hit it up all you like and it
never hits back. Try a tin of P. A. You'll
certainly prefer it after that.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, DECEMBER 10, 1926

VERITABLE RAFFLES RIFLES PHI
GAM HOUSE AND KEYS ARE ISSUED
No longer are the unlocked doors
of the ancient and honorable Hopkins' fraternity houses safe from
the hands of prowling marauders
and sneak thieves. Last Saturday
members of the Phi Gamma Delta
fraternity were visited and entertained—to their sorrow—when a
veritable Raffles emerged from
Fiction into reality.
The story goes as follows: Last
Saturday morning while several
Phi Gams were esconced in their
house, discussing the FreshmanSophomore, rush, which was to take
place that afternoon, there was a
knock on the door. A stranger was
admitted who stated that he was a
member of another fraternity, a
stranger in town, and that, in short,
he was lost. He was persuaded to
come in, and entered into a short
conversation during which it was
mentioned that the house would be
vacant during the afteinoon. The
stranger was then given his directions and he. departed. Shortly
afterwards everyone left for the
rush.
On their return the robbery was
discovered. Jack Griffiths, a stu-

dent at the University, and Frank
Newkirk, late of Williams, who is
in business in the city, were the victims. Jack finds that four of his
shirts, four ties, and a scarf have
departed into unknown possession,
while Frank is grievously lamenting
the loss of a suit of clothes, one
cardcase containing $20, fourteen
shirts, fourteen pairs of socks, and
six new ties. It is reported that the
Phi Gams are having their door
locks repaired and that keys are beinci
issued
to the brothers.

Donald Bonney
Returns To Dorm
Donald Bonney, the victim of the
explosion at the rear of the M. E.
Building which occurred a short
while ago, has returned to the
dormitory on a cane. Bonney,
the first man to graduate from Hopkins with the degree of Gas Engineer, plans to continue his gas-engineering work.
M. Stout has resumed his residence at the dormitory after undergoing an operation for appendicitis
at the Johns Hopkins Hospital.

TAU BETA PI
INITIATES THREE
E. W. Vivell, Anatoli Seletzky, and Edward S. Loane
were initiated into membership of Tau Beta Pi, honorary
engineering fraternity, at the
public initiation yesterday in
assembly. Both Vivell and
Seletzky are seniors, while
Loane is a member of the junior class.
Mr. Thomas F. Hubbard,
himself a graduate of Hopkins and a member of both
Tau Beta Pi and Omicron
Delta Kappa, was the principal speaker at the initiation.
The private initiation was
held last night at the Southern
Hotel, and was followed by
the customary banquet in honor of the new members.

CONGRATULATIONS
The NEws-LETTER wishes to extend its congratulations to
the newly elected members of Tau Beta Pi. While the engineering society is not as widely known as is Phi Beta Kappa, election
to membership is as highly esteemed in engineering circles as
election to Phi Beta Kappa in scholarly circles.
Because of the high standards of the Johns Hopkins Engineering Department, membership in the local chapter is an even
greater honor than it would seem to the average undergraduate.

CHAMPIONS
"Everything comes to him who waits." Once again the patentold adage has been, Nlfilled. Although the Hopuntrustworthy
ly
kins lacrosse team completed its wonderfully successful season
last May, it was not until a few days ago that they received their
official reward.
Intercollegiate lacrosse champions of the country! There
was never any doubt of their deserving the .title, but it gives us
a great deal of satisfaction in knowing that they actually have it.
We rush to congratulate last year's team and Coaches Van Orman
and Schmeisser for bringing to Hopkins another national lacrosse
championship.

REGULATIONS STILL WITH US
Freshman dreams of escaping regulations for the remainder
of the term were rather rudely dashed by the events of last Saturday. Determination and spirit the first year men displayed
in abundance, but these factors did. not prove to be enough, as a
defeat in football and a tie in the rush indicate.
Wish. to congratulate both teams. For an interclass contest
the game- was well played; and the spectators in spite of nearly
freezing to death, seemed to enjoy it.
- Although we sympathize with the freshmen in their shattered
hopes, we trust that now sophomores have won _the right to en-force regulations they will exercise it. Although 'regulations have
often been criticised as both childish and useless, they undoubtedly are a valuable contribution to an introduction to undergraduate life. That they are somewhat childish no one will deny—
but why expect or desire an undergraduate to be completely
grown up.?

YES and NO

mbassy
E
THEATRE

"Just Around the Corner from City Hall Plaza"

Hurrah! An undergrad who isn't afraid to express a thought
We knew that if we kept at it long enough, we should receive
something like the communication we print below. Le voici.
To the Editor of YES AND No:
While I am in an overworked condition, as are all Hopkins
undergraduates, and, as I shall proceed to demonstrate, utterly
incapable of expression, I may fulfill the somewhat Utopian
dream of an undergraduate who thinks, or thinks he thinks. I
cannot be at all sure whether the ravings of "Yes and No" are
prompted by a desire to find "copy" that will fill space or by a
real interest in what the undergraduate thinks, if at all. However, here goes:
I think that a college edtication, for four out of every five
college men, is a waste of time and money. I should exclude the
Engineers who get from their work something that it would be
difficult if not impossible for them to obtain outside an institution of learning. My statement applies particularly to the several hundred students in the College of Arts and Sciences who,
after four years of more or less hard work, receive an A. B. degree and go forth into the "cold world" and attempt to secure
therefrom a decent living. What does such a man get from his
college career to help him be successful in life? What is success
in life from the undergraduate point of view? To me happiness
is success, happiness in doing whatever I may want to do whether
it be drinking liquor or shaping the destinies of nations. These
questions certainly should interest every undergraduate and he
must think about them if he thinks at all.
We are told that college broadens us. What is broadening,
and after all are we certain that broadening is a desirable thing?
May not broadening lead a man to unhappiness by creating in him
desires that he can never satisfy?
We are told that college teaches us to think. Does it? Does
college make a man more capable of solving the many problems
of life which present themselves to him?
I was much interested in an article by Corey Ford in a recent issue of "College Humor" because it explains so well what I
think to be the ideal way to spend four years in college. Mr.
Ford says: "If I had a son (in college) I'd give him all the
money he could possibly spend. I'd tell him to read a great deal
of the books he Wants to read, go to a lot of theaters, and have
parties now and then; and if he came home with a degree I'd
disown him. I'd warn him to stay away from extra-curricular
activities, and I'd tell him to cut a class whenever he found
someone worth talking to." Perhaps these ideas are all wrong
but it seems to me that if it's broadening we are after this system should certainly give it to us. What do you think?
In order to insure sufficient "copy" for "Yes and No" I add
that I do enjoy looking at beautiful women, I do enjoy gambling
in all its forms, and drinking at least sufficient alcohol to make
my heart glad if there is reason why it should be glad. I hereby
challenge the more righteous among us, including the Y. M. C. A.,
to tell me why I shouldn't do these things if I so desire and I
hope that I can find someone who will help me to answer, in connection with college, the old question, "What's it all about ?"

year will be held this evening in
the Commons Room. The SimpsonNIorris orchestra will furnish the
music for the evening's entertainment. Tuxedos will be the apparel

dance will begin at nine and continue to one. A number of tickets

at the popular subscription price of
one fifty per couple. Stags are welcome but not encouraged. Residents
are privileged to invite friends.

R. 0. T. C. HEADQUARTERS
ARE MOVED
Continued from Page 1, Col. 1
tower room, he believed, was to be
utilized by the Librarian.
This statement was verified by
Dr. L. M. Raney, Librarian. The
tower room will perform the function of a repository for duplicate
books and a receiving office. What
are now the postoffice and the telephone room on the ground floor and
the ladies' rest room on the third
floor of Gilman Hall had been primarily intended for these purposes,
said Dr. Raney. Since other necessities prevented such use, the Library stocks have been used instead.
Graduate students have been hampered and valuable spaces in the tiers
and on the tables has been taken
up by idle stock, which will now be
removed to the tower room. Voluminous sets which arrive will be received here also, instead of in the
stacks, so that indexing and cataloging may be done with more care
and with hindrance to no one.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, DECEMBER 10, 1926

VERITABLE RAFFLES RIFLES PHI
GAM HOUSE AND KEYS ARE ISSUED
No longer are the unlocked doors
of the ancient and honorable Hopkins' fraternity houses safe from
the hands of prowling marauders
and sneak thieves. Last Saturday
members of the Phi Gamma Delta
fraternity were visited and entertained—to their sorrow—when a
veritable Raffles emerged from
Fiction into reality.
The story goes as follows: Last
Saturday morning while several
Phi Gams were esconced in their
house, discussing the FreshmanSophomore, rush, which was to take
place that afternoon, there was a
knock on the door. A stranger was
admitted who stated that he was a
member of another fraternity, a
stranger in town, and that, in short,
he was lost. He was persuaded to
come in, and entered into a short
conversation during which it was
mentioned that the house would be
vacant during the afteinoon. The
stranger was then given his directions and he. departed. Shortly
afterwards everyone left for the
rush.
On their return the robbery was
discovered. Jack Griffiths, a stu-

dent at the University, and Frank
Newkirk, late of Williams, who is
in business in the city, were the victims. Jack finds that four of his
shirts, four ties, and a scarf have
departed into unknown possession,
while Frank is grievously lamenting
the loss of a suit of clothes, one
cardcase containing $20, fourteen
shirts, fourteen pairs of socks, and
six new ties. It is reported that the
Phi Gams are having their door
locks repaired and that keys are beinci
issued
to the brothers.

Donald Bonney
Returns To Dorm
Donald Bonney, the victim of the
explosion at the rear of the M. E.
Building which occurred a short
while ago, has returned to the
dormitory on a cane. Bonney,
the first man to graduate from Hopkins with the degree of Gas Engineer, plans to continue his gas-engineering work.
M. Stout has resumed his residence at the dormitory after undergoing an operation for appendicitis
at the Johns Hopkins Hospital.

"Be well-rounded men, broad in your

Surely. there's a lesson for every man—
